climbs.name: Tellurode
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Keith Brueckner, March 1996.

content.description: Toprope the face just left of Patagucci.
Toprope the face between Synchilla Burgers and Peabody's Peril.

Starts in a thin vertical crack, then leans right, becomes horizontal traverse for 5-7 feet then exits over a small lip to a wide ledge.

Two hard moves make this easy climb a 5.7: one at the very beginning, and the one at the very end.
content.protection: C3 cam as a first piece - the best you can do. No big gear needed.

climbs.name: Student Unrest
climbs.fa: Lotus Steele, Criusann Crisdale et al, October 1991

content.description: Ascend using edges and jams up a widish crack.  Angle lowers at the top where the crack becomes increasingly shallow and awkward just to keep you honest.
content.location: Obvious crack at far left of entire formation right before formation height decreases.  (JT West guide description makes it sound like it's maybe a different formation.)

climbs.name: Sitting Around Telling Fishy Stories
climbs.fa: Dwain Warren and Dave Titus, March 1991

content.description: Unprotected face climbing past a horizontal crack gains the security of a grainy crack that ends on a bushy ledge.
content.location:
Located approximately 20 feet right of

Filet of Rock Shark

near the right edge of the rock; it's the right of two cracks which don't reach the ground.

content.description: This is a fairly nice crack route, following the left of two prominent cracks on the right side of the face.
Seemingly easy at the beginning, getting more interesting to the end.
content.protection: Standard rock rack. No need for big gear
content.location: First obvious crack to the right of the gully dividing the wall.

content.description: This route follows the crack just right of Peabody's Peril.  It is loose and unpleasant.
Face climb into a curving thin crack that doesn't reach the ground.
content.location:
Just right of

Student Unrest

on the far left side of the face.

climbs.name: Filet of Rock Shark
climbs.fa: Dwain Warren and Dave Titus, March 1991

content.description: This is a steep, sustained finger crack.
content.protection: Standard rack, with emphasis on smaller pieces
content.location: Just to the right of Nobody's Right Mind

climbs.name: Etta
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Keith Brueckner, March 1996.

content.description: Climb up the gully roughly halfway and then turn 90 degrees left to find a plated climb with an obvious  crack that begins about halfway up.  Negotiate the overhang crux, which is just out of view before finishing through somewhat sloping dishes.
content.protection: To 2" with emphasis on passive for plates.
